awd_titl_txt: Kin Networks, Neighborhood Disadvantage, and Health and Well-Being across the Life Course
awd_abstract_narration:
Living in a disadvantaged neighborhood is associated with worse health than living in a more advantaged context. However, the mechanisms by which neighborhoods influence health and the factors that exacerbate or ameliorate neighborhood influences on health remain understudied. This project investigates the premise that kin dynamics–the size, structure, location, and operation of family networks—play an important role in explaining neighborhood effects on health. By considering kin-related factors, this project lends scientific insight into how neighborhoods affect individual health and health disparities and which individuals are more or less affected. Findings from this project will inform policies and programs aimed at ameliorating health inequalities as part of broader efforts to advance national health, prosperity, and well-being. This project will enhance infrastructure within the research community by documenting the construction of an analytical database for scholars seeking to replicate project methods. The project will also broaden participation of under-represented groups in scientific research by providing research and training opportunities to graduate students across three diverse public universities.   
 
This project will investigate the direct and indirect ways though which neighborhoods may influence health via kin-related dynamics. The project will investigate kin network structure, resources, and function as confounding, suppressing, or moderating factors for neighborhood effects on health. In addition, the project will identify points in the life course at which neighborhood influences on health and well-being may be more or less sensitive to kin network inputs. The project will combine longitudinal data on individual respondents and uniquely rich kinship data from the 1980 to 2017 waves of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID) with information on residential census tracts from the U.S. Census. The sample size is approximately 700,000 person-years corresponding to over 70,000 unique respondents. Health outcomes will be classified into three domains: health status, psychological well-being, and health behaviors. Data will be analyzed with point-in-time descriptive analyses and a series of multilevel regression analyses with individuals clustered within their broader kin networks. The project will rely on specialized approaches including the mediational g-formula approach and structural nested mean models to address the complex issues of selection, reverse causality, and mediation within the longitudinal setting. In doing so, this project will deepen our understanding of the multiple and complex ways in which kin networks may operate in relation to neighborhoods and health. Findings from the project will contribute to sociological theories involving neighborhoods and kin networks as drivers of health outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The project findings advanced knowledge of the spatial structure of kin networks and contributed to theories on family change over time. Our findings largely refute the argument made by some scholars that institutional sources of support have replaced many core family functions, and thus, people are increasingly likely to live farther away from family. Instead, we find that close geographic proximity to kin has been the norm over time for most racial and income groups, with the exception of higher-income non-Latino/a Whites. We attribute these findings to the ongoing cultural and emotional salience of family, as well as the ongoing material support that many families provide to one another. Our findings also reveal other important differences in family proximity and support by gender, race, class, and life course stage. The findings speak to how family support-exchange is structured over the life course and depends on individual and family factors, which has implications for health, poverty, caregiving, and other key topics in Sociology and related disciplines. The project findings have also prompted us to begin exploring the interplay between residential mobility, distance to kin, and family support over the life course. These intellectual insights were disseminated via peer-reviewed publications and at academic conferences.

Broader Impacts

The project had several broader impacts. The project contributed to scientific and public understanding of the ongoing importance of family networks for supporting the health and well-being of individuals at various stages of life, from childhood to older adulthood. Findings from the project were disseminated to the public via media outlets, and to students in our classrooms.

The project contributed to the training and career outcomes of graduate students and post-doctoral researchers in Sociology. Ten early-career scholars (graduate students and post-docs) were supported over the course of the project and received important opportunities for training and professional development. Several have since graduated and obtained academic or applied research positions.

The project contributed to research infrastructure by making code and metadata using the PSID data publicly available. New research into longitudinal family dynamics is now more possible with the PSID. The project expanded the utility of this important and widely-used national dataset, opening opportunities to new research and insights.



Last Modified: 01/03/2025
Modified by: Amy L Spring

The project findings have also prompted us to begin exploring the interplay between residential mobility, distance to kin, and family support over the life course.
